text:
This section offers a step-by-step guide to using TALL: from installation and preprocessing to analysis, AI support, and export options.



TALL is an R package with an embedded Shiny interface.



R ‚â• 4.2.0

Recommended: RStudio






You can install the official release of TALL from the Comprehensive R Archive Network CRAN and updated monthly.

if (!require(‚Äúpak‚Äù, quietly=TRUE)) install.packages(‚Äúpak‚Äù)
pak::pkg_install(‚Äútall‚Äù)




If you want access to the most recent features and updates not yet available on CRAN, you can install the development version directly from our GitHub repository with:

if (!require(‚Äúpak‚Äù, quietly=TRUE)) install.packages(‚Äúpak‚Äù)
pak::pkg_install(‚Äúmassimoaria/tall‚Äù)





tall::tall()







Users can:

Import .txt, .csv, .bib, .xlsx, .json
Resume previous sessions from .tall files
Use sample datasets (e.g., BBC, Bibliometrix, Tweets)
Import directly from Biblioshiny
Load Wikipedia pages




Importing data in TALL






On the first launch, TALL will prompt you to set a working folder.
All files and results will be saved here, and settings are retained across sessions.



Working folder configuration






TALL includes a complete preprocessing workflow:

Tokenization and normalization

Lemmatization & PoS-tagging using UD v2.15
Special entity recognition

Multi-word and custom-term tagging

Supports 57 languages, with 87 models including domain-specific variants (e.g., social, news).



Preprocessing panel






Explore:

Term frequencies

Vocabulary metrics and indexes

Wordclouds

Keyword-in-context (KWIC)

Semantic ego networks




KWIC interface






Choose between:

LCA (Lexical Correspondence Analysis)

Hierarchical clustering (Tandem Analysis)

Reinert clustering

Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA)

Adjust clustering parameters and visualize outputs:



LCA plot and dendrogram






Build and explore:

Term-Term networks

Document-Document matrices

Apply filters, compute modularity, detect communities




Network analysis example






Choose from:

Hu & Liu

Loughran-McDonald (finance)

NRC Emotion Lexicon

Context-aware scores include valence shifters (negators, amplifiers‚Ä¶).



Polarity distribution






Summarize texts using TextRank:

Graph-based ranking of sentences
Adjustable length

Highlighted relevance per sentence




Text summarization example






Activate the built-in TALL AI assistant:

Interprets patterns in clustering, LDA, sentiment, and networks
Suggests labels, explanations, and critical insights
Integrates via Google Gemini API




TALL AI assistant interface


See the TALL AI page for full details.




You can:

Export to Excel or PNG

Save current progress as a .tall file

Add results to a cumulative report




Export options







Use the Info & References tabs in every module

Consult this documentation anytime

Contact the authors via the About page

Visit GitHub for updates


TALL makes powerful text analysis accessible ‚Äî now with the guidance of AI.

title: Download
text:
üì• Install Instructions

  
    TALL can be installed in two ways, depending on whether you want the stable version or the latest development version.
    Make sure to have the latest version of R installed.
  

  
    
    
      
      Stable Version
      
        Official release from CRAN, updated monthly.
      
      if (!require("pak", quietly=TRUE)) install.packages("pak")
pak::pkg_install("tall")
    

    
    
      
      Development Version
      
        Install the latest development version directly from GitHub.
      
      if (!require("pak", quietly=TRUE)) install.packages("pak")
pak::pkg_install("massimoaria/tall")
    
  

  
  
    ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Run TALL
    library("tall")
tall()

title: üß™ Use Cases
text:
This page showcases practical examples of how TALL can be used to explore and analyze text corpora across various domains. Each example illustrates a complete workflow ‚Äî from data import to final interpretation ‚Äî including optional use of TALL AI for insight generation.



Goal: Identify main topics and sentiment trends in news stories.


386 short articles from the Entertainment section of the BBC News website (English language).




Import BBC dataset from sample collection
Preprocess with tokenization, lemmatization, and entity tagging
Explore vocabulary: term frequency, wordcloud, KWIC for terms like ‚Äúactor‚Äù, ‚Äúaward‚Äù
Apply LDA to detect latent topics (e.g., celebrity deaths, film reviews)
Visualize polarity across articles using the Hu & Liu lexicon
Summarize key articles using TextRank




BBC topic modeling


TALL AI Support: Suggests meaningful topic labels and provides narrative interpretation of polarity trends.





Goal: Extract conceptual structure and sentiment in bibliometric research.


444 scientific abstracts citing the Bibliometrix R package, with metadata (authors, year, journal).




Import from .bib or Biblioshiny export
Tokenize + lemmatize scientific vocabulary
Perform Correspondence Analysis (LCA) to identify clusters of research themes
Apply Reinert Clustering for topic segmentation
Build Co-occurrence Network to map related concepts
Filter by metadata (year, author, journal) for trend detection




Bibliometrix network


TALL AI Support: Describes main research trends and offers critical reflection on emerging clusters.





Goal: Understand customer feedback and emotions in airline-related tweets.


14,640 tweets about major U.S. airlines collected in February 2015.




Import CSV file with raw tweets
Preprocess with domain-specific PoS model (social media language)
Tag special entities like @mentions, #hashtags, emojis
Run Sentiment Analysis with NRC Emotion Lexicon
Build Ego Network around key terms (e.g., ‚Äúdelay‚Äù, ‚Äúservice‚Äù)
Cluster topics via LCA + hierarchical analysis




US Airlines sentiment


TALL AI Support: Interprets emotions and proposes thematic summaries of clusters (e.g., delays, praise, complaints).





Goal: Compare discourse structures across domains using open web sources.


Import and compare Wikipedia pages about climate change, sustainable tourism, and machine learning.




Import Wikipedia pages using title input
Preprocess and tag lemmas and entities
Create term √ó document matrix
Run LDA and visualize dominant topics
Compare lexical richness and structure across articles




Wikipedia comparison


TALL AI Support: Identifies discursive strategies, labels overlapping themes, and suggests summary narratives.





TALL is flexible and scalable for use in:

Social science research

Digital humanities

Public policy analysis

Journalism and media studies

Education and learning analytics

Marketing and brand sentiment monitoring


Have a use case to share? Contribute on GitHub or get in touch via the About page.

title: Key Features of TALL
text:
TALL (Text Analysis for All) is a powerful and user-friendly R Shiny application designed to democratize access to advanced text mining tools. Built on the R ecosystem, TALL supports researchers, students, and professionals in performing quantitative and qualitative text analyses ‚Äî without writing a single line of code.



TALL now includes TALL AI, an integrated artificial intelligence assistant that enhances users‚Äô analytical experience by providing:

Automated interpretation of statistical results
Critical discussion prompts on detected patterns
Conceptual guidance during topic modeling, clustering, and sentiment analysis
Contextual suggestions to support exploration and hypothesis generation

TALL AI is powered by cutting-edge LLMs and can be activated by connecting a free API key from Google Studio AI.




From raw text to interpretative insight, TALL provides a structured workflow:

Import text data from multiple formats (.txt, .csv, .bib, Wikipedia, Biblioshiny, etc.)
Pre-process using integrated NLP tools (tokenization, lemmatization, PoS-tagging, semantic compression)
Analyze through diverse modules: word frequencies, co-occurrences, correspondence analysis, clustering, topic modeling, sentiment analysis
Visualize & export results for reports or reuse






Load raw texts or pre-tagged datasets
Import .tall structured files for session recovery
Direct export from Biblioshiny
Add metadata or split/group documents dynamically





The preprocessing engine integrates:

Universal Dependencies based models (v2.15) for accurate PoS-tagging and lemmatization
Support for 57 languages, including specific variants for domains such as social media, news, and scientific writing, covering a total of 87 pre-trained models
Semantic tagging of special entities and automatic multi-word expression creation
Customizable token/lemma filtering and grouping

All preprocessing steps are modular, transparent, and reproducible, ensuring high-quality input for downstream analyses.





Vocabulary and TF-IDF distributions
Word clouds
Word in Context (KWIC) and semantic ego-networks

Users can explore specific terms in context, across documents and sentences.




Multiple methods are available:

Lexical Correspondence Analysis (LCA)
Hierarchical clustering (Tandem Analysis)
Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA)
Reinert Clustering

All methods include parameter tuning, model selection (e.g.¬†CaoJuan index), and graphical outputs.





Build co-occurrence networks from term/document matrices
Perform community detection using clustering algorithms
Analyze network metrics (centrality, density, modularity)
Explore networks of words, multi-words, emojis, or entities





Includes multiple lexicons:

Hu & Liu (general sentiment)
Loughran-McDonald (financial)
NRC Emotion Lexicon (emotional tones)

TALL computes polarity scores with context-aware rules (negators, amplifiers, de-amplifiers) and logistic scaling.




TALL uses TextRank, a graph-based extractive summarization algorithm that:

Ranks sentences by centrality in a similarity network
Produces adjustable summaries (concise or detailed)
Visualizes sentence relevance and structure






Save intermediate or final results in .tall files
Export graphs and tables in Excel or image formats
Automatically add results to a cumulative report





TALL is fully open source and available on GitHub. Users are encouraged to contribute, report issues, or extend its capabilities.




Whether you are a linguist, data scientist, social scientist, or just exploring text analytics, TALL offers a robust, intuitive environment to uncover meaning in texts ‚Äî now with AI-powered guidance.
Ready to explore your texts? Get started now!

title: ‚ú® TALL AI ‚Äì Interpreting Text, Intelligently
text:
TALL AI is the new artificial intelligence assistant embedded in the TALL ecosystem. It empowers users with automated interpretation and critical support across the entire text analysis pipeline ‚Äî transforming data exploration into a guided reasoning process.



Whether you‚Äôre analyzing political narratives, consumer reviews, scientific abstracts, or historical sources ‚Äî TALL AI adapts to your needs and helps you make sense of words at scale.







TALL AI is a large language model‚Äìbased assistant designed to work in tandem with TALL‚Äôs analytical modules. Its main goal is to help users understand, discuss, and critically reflect on the outputs of their textual analyses ‚Äî without requiring programming or domain-specific expertise.




TALL AI provides support across several stages of analysis:



Highlights vocabulary distribution anomalies
Suggests interpretations of lexical diversity and concentration
Flags dominant linguistic patterns (e.g., jargon, recurring constructs)





Labels emergent clusters and topics with clear summaries
Connects results to broader conceptual themes
Detects semantic overlaps or drifts across time, domains, or authorship





Describes network structure (density, modularity, centrality)
Interprets semantic communities
Identifies key connectors and thematic bridges





Explains sentiment trends
Discusses the meaning of polarized terms in context
Highlights valence shifts and emotional dynamics





Suggests critical readings of summaries
Flags missing narrative elements
Helps rephrase or refine automated outputs






TALL AI is powered by Google Gemini APIs, integrated into TALL via a lightweight authentication layer. Users must:

Register at Google Studio AI
Generate a free API key for Gemini models
Enter the key in TALL‚Äôs settings panel

No advanced configuration is needed ‚Äî just plug and play.





A linguist uses TALL AI to interpret co-occurrence networks from literary texts
A social scientist receives AI-assisted summaries of clusters in political discourse
A student explores AI-generated commentary on the sentiment polarity of tweets
A researcher reflects on LDA outputs with labels and hypotheses suggested by TALL AI












Without TALL AI
With TALL AI




Raw tables and graphs
Interpreted patterns and themes


Technical statistics
Explained indicators and contextualization


Trial-and-error labeling
Suggested cluster/topic labels


Manual sensemaking
Guided exploratory reasoning



TALL AI transforms results into insight.





No textual content is stored or reused by TALL AI
API usage is always local and user-controlled
Interpretations are suggestions, not deterministic outputs

All interactions are documented, optional, and reproducible.
